headline.main: Poll Finds Most Americans Have Not Prepared for a Terror Attack

docs.abstract: The New York Times poll finds that Americans are divided about whether US is prepared to deal with another terrorist attack, but most have done nothing to prepare for attack themselves and are not worried that they or relative will become terrorist victim; David Ropeik, who teaches risk communications at Harvard, says 'optimism bias' intuitive to humans is at work (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are closely divided on whether they think the United States is prepared to deal with another terrorist attack, but the overwhelming majority have done nothing to prepare for such an attack themselves, according to a recent New York Times poll. The poll found that most Americans are not worried that they or a family member will become a victim of terrorism, with the majority of the respondents saying they do nothing different even when the government raises the terror-alert level.
docs.snippet: Americans are closely divided on whether they think the United States is prepared to deal with another terrorist attack, according to a recent New York Times poll.

headline.main: A Milk Shake and Fries With Your Surgery?

docs.abstract: Prof Alan B Cohen explains that fast-food outlets in hospitals are profitable source of revenue but, perversely, also assure hospitals of 'repeat' business from patients with obesity-related ailments
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Burgers for the Health Professional'' (news article, Oct. 26):
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Burgers for the Health Professional'' (news article, Oct. 26):

headline.main: Burgers for the Health Professional; If the Hospital Cafeteria Is a McDonald's, Is Fast Food Still Unhealthy?

docs.lead_paragraph: Under the smiling clown-face of Ronald McDonald, a woman and her 5-year-old daughter had spread before them a burger, Chicken McNuggets and fries. Nearby, a young couple were enjoying two Quarter Pounders with cheese. A neurologist was downing some hot cakes. Just a few of the billions served, as the company proudly proclaims beneath its golden arches.
docs.snippet: Even as obesity and its consequences are increasingly taxing the health care system, fast food places are serving as hospital cafeterias.
